1. All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this Trade.

2. SCOPE OF WORK

This specification and the accompanying heating drawings are intended to provide for a complete system of Gravity Warm Air Heating in the building. The Contractor shall take all measurements at the building, set out all work and be responsible for the accuracy of same. He shall provide all labour, transportation, material and plant and give his personal and constant attention to the work and be responsible for any damage done.

3. VISIT THE SITE

The Contractor must visit the Site and see the conditions under which the work will be done and govern himself accordingly.

4. MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP

All materials shall be new and the best of their respective kinds, sound and free from defects.

Workmanship shall be of the best and all work shall be done in a neat manner with due attention given to the grading of all warm air leaders, and making connections. All connections shall be made to provide free and unobstructed flow and shall be made as tight as possible and in a manner consistent with the best practice.

5. WARM AIR FURNACE

Furnish and set up complete in the basement, where shown on plan, one first grade furnace as described on drawing, having a rated output equivalent to that called for on the plan. The furnace shall have a double casing; and shall be equipped with manually operated chain, controlled draft and check dampers, water pan and a complete set of firing tools.

6. SMOKE PIPE

Provide and install galvanized iron smoke pipe of a gauge and diameter called for on plan. This smoke pipe shall have a close fitting manually operated key damper in horizontal run.
Provide suitable collar at a point where smoke pipe enters chimney.

7. LEADERS

Provide and install circular warm air leaders of sizes noted on plan, made up of bright tin or 26 gauge galvanized iron, with locked seams. Joints shall be lapped not less than 1\(\frac{3}{4}\)" and shall be beaded and soldered to make tight connections. All leaders shall be carefully connected to furnaces, cold air register boxes and wall stacks with all necessary elbows, twistings, boots, transitions, sections, etc., as may be required to provide a complete job. Leaders shall be supported from joists and shall be installed with a rise of not less than one inch per lineal foot.

All leaders, except as noted on plan, shall be provided with dampers located not more than 2'-0" from furnace cons.

Where leaders are run within 1" of any woodwork, the woodwork in the immediate vicinity shall be protected with sheet asbestos wall board.

Where leaders pass through partitions, galvanized iron flanged sleeves shall be provided, the flanges having diameters sufficient to cover opening in partition. The sleeves shall be made of No. 24 gauge galvanized iron.

8. STACKS

All warm air stacks shall be made up of bright tin or No. 26 gauge galvanized iron, and shall be of sizes as noted on drawing.

9. RETURN AIR DUCTS AND LEADERS.

From the cold air register faces located where shown on plan, provide and connect up return air ducts of sizes and gauges noted on plan. These return air ducts shall be fastened directly to the underside of the joists and run to the furnace room where round return air leaders shall be connected therefrom to cold air shoes, typically as shown on large scale section. Care shall be taken to make all joints as tight as possible, and all panels shall be cross broken to provide rigidity.

10. ELBOWS

All elbows shall be not less than 3 piece style, and all shall be adjustable. Care shall be taken to obtain tight connections between elbows and leaders.

11. REGISTERS AND FACES

Supply and install baseboard and floor registers where shown of sizes noted on plan. Supply registers shall be provided with movable louvres and suitable for connection to register boxes.

Return air faces shall be cast with bronze finish or hardwood. Wall faces adjacent to stair well or first floor shall be steel with bronze finish of sizes as shown.
12. COMPLETION

Upon completion of the work the Contractor shall remove all rubbish and waste materials resulting from his work and leave the whole system in perfect working order.

13. RECORD PLANS

During progress of the work, the Contractor shall keep a record of all changes to the original plans. Upon completion he shall forward one set of blueprints with changes clearly recorded in red to the Chief Engineer. Blueprints for this purpose shall be furnished by the Department.

14. GUARANTEE

The Contractor will be called upon to guarantee his work for a period of one year after date of acceptance by the Department. He shall make good or replace any defect arising in his work during that period, at his own expense as soon as possible after being notified that such defect has appeared.

15. HEATING SCHEDULE OF SIZES

Equipment listed under condition table "C" on sheet No. H-1 Index No. 827 of the blue prints should be provided for this school.

Referring to my letter of November 29th, and your reply of December 9th, regarding the possibility of installing a bin feed stoker for our new school in the Fort William Reserve, I wish to report the contractors have just informed me that an iron fireman would actually pay in dollars over a period of four years. Assuming we secure a janitor to look after the furnace, it would cost approximately $120.00 a year. Over a period of four years, we would have expended $480.00. The saving on fuel is approximately $54.00 per year which would mean a saving of $216.00 over a period of four years, bringing the total saving over a period of four years, to $390.00.

Two local firms would be willing to install a bin feed iron fireman immediately, and render their account next April. On a recent visit to our Mission Bay Indian Day School, Mrs. Osborne, the teacher, informed me that she is very anxious to transfer to the new school now under construction at Mission Bay Reserve. A distance of four miles separates the two Indian Day Schools on this reservation. Mrs. Osborne said she did hope the Department would recommend an iron fireman. She is one of the best teachers we have ever had in the Agency, and if it is at all possible, I would appreciate if an iron fireman could be installed.

Dear Sir:

In line with our conversation, re Mountain Village School.

As you know there is no natural drainage in this area, it will be necessary to have a Sump pump installed in the basement.

We will make necessary Sump Pit connecting to the tile drainage system under the floor, instal Sump Pump, cut necessary hole in concrete wall for discharge pipe, supply and instal necessary discharge pipes and prepare sufficient surface drain from end of discharge pipe.

For the above work, we can supply all necessary material and labour for the sum of One Hundred and Forty-five Dollars ($145.00)

Yours very truly,

"Joe Skopyk"

We are disappointed to learn from your letter of the 13th instant that the new Mountain Village School has been erected on low land and consequently that a sump pump will be required for drainage purposes.

Was it not possible to obtain a better location so that the drainage would be satisfactory? However, I suppose there is nothing much can be done about the matter now and the only thing we can do is authorize the installation of the sump pump. It is noted that the cost of the necessary labour and materials will be $145.00. An expenditure of this amount is approved.

Mountain Village I.D. School,

Your letter under date of March 16th to hand at this Agency, in acknowledgment of Mr. Burk's letter and we note your authorization for the purchase of a sump-pump.

Concerning your comments on the drainage problem, it appears there was no alternative but to erect the school in this location. The terrain of the Mountain Village Section of the Fort William Reserve is not in consonance with the given name, and is low lying land. However, to complement this, the school is otherwise ideally situated in an advantageous location and much favourable comment should be heard from all who see it.

I have spoken to the contractors and have their assurance that they will be all through at the school about a week in advance of the stipulated date, which I understand is 31st March. If we had a teacher, it would be fitting should one of your officials in this section be on hand for the opening. However, we have no teacher, and in any event it is unlikely that the time could be spared, for the occasion is not so auspicious as to warrant the loss of time by anyone from HQ's at this busy time of year.

N.V. Feltier,
Port Arthur Agency.

Re: Mountain Village Day School
Fort William Indian Reserve.

Pursuant to the inspection of the above completed school, the School Inspector Mr. A. J. Doucet seemed quite well satisfied with the construction. He mentioned that the window in the bedroom in the residence section of the school was not as per the plans, and that it should have been of the casement or moveable type, and not "fast" as was the case. He also mentioned that the contractor was responsible for the levelling off of the earth piled up around the school from the excavation made.

These matters have been drawn to the attention of the contractor. He has assured us that he will remedy the window situation at once, and that he will approach the sub-contractor who did the excavation to have him level off the pile of excavated earth. There still will remain a large amount of ground work, and landscaping to be done, as stated by Mr. Doucet. He intimated that authority would be available for the carrying out of this work with an Indian using his team, and Indian labour. We would welcome receiving authority in writing from you to carry out these ground improvements as surveyed by Mr. Doucet.

J. G. Burk,
Superintendent.
May 31, 1948.

Mr. J.G. Burk, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Port Arthur, Ont.

We have your letter of the 26th instant, file 210-1 (9), regarding the Mountain Village School and it is noted that the contractor will give immediate attention to the matters on which Mr. Doucet reported.

Regarding the latter part of your letter, we are not prepared to spend any further amount until the contractor has completed his work according to the specifications and contract which you have.

It is not our intention to do any extensive landscaping and as stated above, will wait a further report from you before deciding on any expenditure.

Bernard F. Henry

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY.

Re: Inspection of Mountain Village Indian Day School.

At the inspection of this school, I noticed that the windows in the bedroom of the teacherage were not casement windows. I was unable to meet the Contractor while there but I left instructions with the Clerk as Mr. Burk was absent, to have these windows changed. It is essential to have fresh air in the bedroom.

The school itself has been very well built and the Contractor has done a commendable job. Unfortunately, the school has been set a little low. It could very easily have been two feet higher which would have avoided the necessity of a sump pump and at the same time would have improved the ground. The levelling off should be done by the Contractor. There is a small hill which drains towards the school. This may have to be levelled. I have asked the Clerk to have an estimate made and submit it to this office for consideration.

I also visited the Mission Bay Day School and there interviewed Mrs. Augustine Osborne.
I do not see any objection to transferring her to the Mountain Village School. She appears to be active and her principles of education are sound. Possibly, a younger person could contribute more towards the activities of the school but the dearth of teachers, I believe, make it necessary to give her this consideration.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Connett,
Supervisor, Vocational Training.

The work involved was the removal from close proximity to the school of the outside toilets, to a point about 25 feet distant from the old location. Further work involved cutting of grass in the school area, and the hauling of gravel for the toilet beds. A payroll showing labour with team also is involved. A start has been made to landscape the grounds, the need of which was noted by Mr. Doucet on his last visit to the school.

MOUNTAIN VILLAGE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL - INSPECTION REPORT

Date of Inspection - September 25, 1949.

School and Location
This is a new school following plan 637. It is well located on the highway one and a half miles from the outskirts of Fort William. The only difficulty is with regard to the drainage of the basement and the school yard. In the spring there is seepage from the mountain back of the school and it will probably be necessary to run a tile drain across the playground.

There is electricity and running water in this school with a flush toilet for the teacher. There are dry closets for the children.

Teacher
Mrs. Osborne is over 70 years of age but is still a very efficient and capable teacher. Her children tested well and it is obvious that she is in complete control of the classroom. Her teaching methods are fairly modern and she handles her class well.

Recommendations
1. That an effort be made to retain the services of this teacher or that she be considered for a transfer to a hospital school.
2. That drainage be installed as above.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

The site I have chosen is on high ground where good drainage will be obtained. Also, being close to the rapids plenty of good water will be available the year round as the rapids do not freeze over. The Teachers quarters will face the Lake and the wall of windows will be on the South side.

I trust that tenders will be called and the contract awarded early this spring so that the school will be completed in time for the opening of the fall term.

J.F. Lockhart,

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian Day School North West Bay.

This is to acknowledge receipt of your permission to extend the date of tender for the above school until May 28th. I wish to assure you that I appreciate this action on your part.

Unfortunately, I was grounded, because of adverse flying conditions, at Armstrong, where I am putting up a building for the Ontario Department of Public Works, and was unable to get through to Fort Frances. I sent a query to the Superintendent of your Indian Agency, at Fort Frances, requesting certain information regarding the conditions. However, he seemed to feel bound by the general conditions of the tender to not make any statement. This has caused me to feel that there must be some type of difficulty to be encountered at this site, and I, therefore, feel it would be unwise for me to make any tender until I have made thorough examination of the location, as instructed by Specifications.

I shall proceed to examine this site on my next trip to Fort Frances, and if, for any reason, the contract for this job is deferred, I would appreciate your giving me an opportunity to place my tender, if same is called at a future date.

OTTAWA, AUGUST 5, 1949.

REQUEST FOR THE GRANT OF THE PRIVILEGE OF CONSIDERATION.

Requesting authority to accept the revised tender of Tomkins' Hardware, Limited, of Eno, Ontario, amounting to $10,000.00, for the construction of a one-room school building at Nortons Bay, on the Nanticoke Reserve, in the Fort Frances Indian Agency, Province of Ontario.

Two extra copies of Order-in-Council are required.

THE MINISTERIAL OFFICE OF THE DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

THE P.G. 362 of June 16, 1949, authorized the acceptance of the tender of Tomkins' Hardware Limited, of Eno, Ontario, for the erection of a one-room school and teacher's residence at Nortons Bay, on the Nanticoke Reserve, in the Fort Frances Indian Superintendentcy, Province of Ontario, for the amount of $8,500.00;

THAT the only other tender received for the erection of this building in answer to our advertisement was that of North American Lumber and Supply Company, Fort Frances, Ontario, in the amount of $7,500.00;

THAT representations have been received from Tomkins' Hardware, Limited, of Eno, Ontario, that they cannot adhere to their original tender because the tend to the school has not been completed and that freight charges will therefore be double that which they had anticipated in original tender;

THAT they have submitted a new tender in the amount of $10,000.00;

THAT we have advertised this identical standard school elsewhere in Canada and have had tendered other tenders in the approximate amount of $10,500.00 up to $12,000.00;

THAT Departmental officials recommend the acceptance of this new tender of Tomkins' Hardware, Limited, of Eno, Ontario, in an amount of $10,000.00;

THAT funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends the acceptance of the revised tender of Tomkins' Hardware, Limited, of Eno, Ontario, for the erection of this one-room school and teacher's residence, for the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

- Northwest Bay Indian Day School -

The acceptance of the tender of Tompkins' Hardware Limited, of Eno, Ontario, was authorized by P.C. 3062 of June 16, 1949, for the construction of the above school. This tender was in the amount of $8,563.25 and was the lower of two received. The higher tender was that of North American Lumber and Supply Company, Fort Frances, Ontario, in the amount of $17,528.51.

Please find attached correspondence from Mr. Tompkins of the above mentioned firm, requesting that due to changed transportation conditions, the contract price be changed to $10,000.

As we have advertised for this identical school elsewhere and tenders accepted have ranged from $10,500.00 up to $12,000.00 for single buildings, I would recommend that the submission to Council be approved for the acceptance of this revised tender. Mr. Tompkins is a good and reliable builder but, naturally, he could not anticipate that this road would not be completed and that he would have these higher transportation expenses to meet.

Director.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 17 AUGUST 1949.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 3rd August, 1949 from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT P.C. 3062 of June 15, 1949, authorized the acceptance of the tender of Tompkins' Hardware Limited, of Eno, Ontario, for the erection of a one-room school and teacher's residence at Northwest Bay on the Nainatecheening Reserve, in the Fort Frances Indian Superintendency, Province of Ontario, for the amount of $6,583.33;

THAT the only other tender received for the erection of this building in answer to the Department's advertisement was that of North American Lumber and Supply Company, Fort Frances, Ontario, in the amount of $17,583.51;

THAT representations have been received from Tompkins' Hardware, Limited, of Eno, Ontario, that they cannot adhere to their original tender because the road to the school has not been completed and that freighting charges will therefore be double that which they had anticipated in original tender;

THAT they have submitted a new tender in the amount of $10,000.00;

THAT this identical standard school has been advertised elsewhere in Canada and authorized other tenders have been received in the approximate amounts of $10,500.00 up to $12,000.00;

THAT Departmental officials recommend the acceptance of the said new tender of Tompkins' Hardware, Limited, of Eno, Ontario, in an amount of $10,000.00;

THAT funds are available for this purpose in Vote 229, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted to accept the revised tender of Tompkins' Hardware, Limited, of Eno, Ontario, for the erection of the said one-room school and teacher's residence, for the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).

Re: File 499-5 (E)

I am returning herewith contract forms between the Department and Tompkins' Hardware Ltd. of Emo, Ont. for the erection of a Day School on the North West Bay Indian Reserve.

It is very disappointing that this firm did not go ahead with this building immediately upon receipt of advise that they had been awarded the contract. It is true that transportation of material to this reserve is quite difficult, however this problem was well known to those tendering in the first place. I have no doubt that if we had not started to build a road into this Reserve that the school would of been built by this time. Good progress is being made on the road but it will not be finished this fall.

I understand from Mr. Tompkins that he is writing further to the Department.

J.F. Lockhart,

Sir,

We desire the following appeal:

"Her Majesty agrees to establish schools for instruction in such Reserves hereby made as Her Government of the Dominion of Canada may deem advisable whenever the Indians of the Reserve shall desire it."

And whereas for reasons hereinafter set forth the day school fails to meet our requirements and whereas we believe that a good Boarding School established on this Reserve would—

Therefore we, the Chiefs and Councilors of the Berens River Band do humbly pray the present Government to grant us such a school.

Our reasons for saying that the present day school does not meet requirements are as follows:

Fishing and hunting—The occupation by which we make our living takes so many of us away—sometimes for months at a time that our children have no chance to attend.

REQUEST and AGREEMENT of Chief Berens and his councillors made at Berens' River this 8th day of July, 1912.

We Respectfully Request that the Indian Department build us a Boarding school with accommodation for eighty pupils, for the education of our children at Berens' River, Poplar River, Little Grand Rapids, Pekangaskum, and some other small Reserves where the Saulteaux language is spoken.

And we further request that the Methodist church manage this Boarding school according to the rules and regulations of the Indian Department.

For this purpose we will give the Indian Department a block of land, excluding the Methodist Mission property, said land to be described as follows:

The South Boundary the Berens' River, the North Boundary the North line of the Reserve, the West Boundary to be the West line of the Government school site extended straight North to the North of the Reserve, the East Boundary to be a line parallel with the West Boundary and drawn North and South 65 chains distant. This block of land contains about 320 acres exclusive of the Methodist Mission property of 77.15 acres.

We also agree to provide 80 pupils for this school one year after we have notice that this boarding school is to be built and we further promise to keep this school full of pupils as long as we have sufficient children on the above mentioned Reserves.

We also agree that we will not ask for any day school on any of the above Reserves.

We sign this request and promises believing them to be binding upon our successors in office and in harmony with the wish of a very large majority of our people.

Sir,

Your letter of November 29th received and contents noted.

As I have been asked to give a report of educational conditions on this Reserve I may say first - so far as I can see from my two years' observation on the Reserve, that the Day School are a failure in educating the children. Of course there are always two or three families who are glad to avail themselves of the advantages of the Day School. There are on this Reserve about seventy children of school age. This quarter I have fifty-six on the register with an average attendance of fifteen to sixteen each. This is the largest enrollment since March 1907. I believe the large number enrolled is partly due to the services of the native policeman who has been visiting the houses and persuading the people to send their children to school.
There are many reasons why the children do not attend regularly. Perhaps the chief reason is the indifference of the parents. Many of them live quite a distance from the school, and when the tracks are bad, or the weather stormy, the children cannot come. Some of them are not properly clothed. There were several this winter who could not have attended if Mr. Lowe had not supplied them with clothing.

Another reason for poor attendance are the fishing seasons. About the middle of May and sometimes earlier, the people leave their homes and move to the mouth of the river; where they remain until August. The distance is too great for any to attend school. They are home only a short time after this, until they are away again for fall fishing. Very soon after that the river freezes, and then there is a time again when they cannot attend. During two or more weeks last fall, the were not more than five in attendance.

The weather was so mild, the ice was not safe to cross. Every year is not as bad as the last one. Hunting also takes some of the people away. Every winter some of the families leave the Reserve for weeks and camp several miles away, the men only returning to trade their furs and meat.

Compulsory attendance at Day School (when possible) would certainly help to a great degree; but the very best improvement would be a Boarding School on the Reserve and the attendance made...
I spent about a year and a half in the Norway House Boarding School and could see the good it did not only to the children in the school, but also as an example to all on the Reserve. In the Boarding Schools they learn English for the reasons that they hear it all day and are compelled to speak it. In the Day Schools it is almost impossible to make them use the English they know; and when they leave school in the afternoon, they hear nothing but their own language. The people on this Reserve and also on the Red River Reserve will not send their children to the Industrial Schools. We have been here a year and a half and were at Oxford House three years, and although Mr. Louie did his very best he was not able to secure one child for the Industrials.

In reference to a mid-day meal being served in the school room—would a teacher be expected to do the work without extra remuneration? No matter how simple the meal might be I cannot see how a teacher would be able to prepare it without taking time from the regular school hours. It would be quite impossible to prepare and serve a meal in the school-room here. However, the old School House is close to the one in present use and could easily be fitted up. Cooking utensils, stove, table and a few other articles would be needed. There are two or three Indian women who could be hired (say a week or two at a time) to prepare the meal under the superintendence of the teacher.
In absence of the teacher I feel certain the supplies could not be procured here this year at least. The Hudson Bay Co. trading post is the base of supplies on the Reserve and as a rule they Co. themselves are short by the time the spring boat arrives.

I trust you will find this letter satisfactory and at least some slight assistance.

Yours Respectfully,

Henriette A. Lewis
(Mrs. J. W. Lewis)

Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of February 7.

In regard to the serving of a mid-day meal, I may say again, I do not think, in fact I may feel sure, a teacher could not do it and the class-room work also. That is and attend to the work properly. I have had enough of experience with new Indian girls, to know how much or rather how little they can do about cooking etc.

Older girls are mentioned as helpers if you will notice by my return, there are but three girls over twelve years of age, who come to school or are at all likely to attend.

If I may be allowed to suggest a plan, it would be this—that the teacher be given a certain amount of money with which she could hire an assistant from among the women on the Reserve. This would not be necessary the whole term, but during December, March and part of April, January.

To be quite frank, I might say, the only way to
Keep the children at school certain times of the year, would help to feed the families. The parents will have the reserves, at least in this part of the country. This cannot be helped, so long as their means of livelihood is such as fishing and hunting. What is really needed and very badly needed is a Boarding School.

I understand that in the White Schools in Manitoba they are granting a weeks holiday during Easter. Does this rule apply to Indian Day Schools? What stated holidays are thus for these schools?

Dear Sir:-

I have consulted with Mr. Lowe, our Missionary at Serens River, and also with Mrs. Lowe, who has been teaching there, re the serving of a hot meal to the children attending the Day School. I may say that they are not favorable to going to the trouble and expense of cooking a hot meal. Personally I endorse the position they take. However, we have decided to compromise in a way that will be very much better, both for the Department and the School. It is that the Department supplement the usual supply of hard tack biscuits with, say, an equal quantity of mixed biscuits such as Cream Sodas, Sultanas, Abernethy, Fruit Gingerbread Biscuits, with possibly tea and Bovril. This last was suggested by Dr. Grain, who was present when we were discussing the question. If this meets the approval of the Department, the following order to supplement the hard tack, would fill the bill for probably a year:

360 lbs Sodas
120 lbs Sultanas
120 lbs Abernethy
120 lbs Fruit Gingerbread

The supplying of a meal to children whose parents, compared to white people can live in luxury, as far as food is concerned, if they will only take the trouble to place their hands upon it, will not have the effect of training the Indians to be self reliant, but if properly attended to by a person other than the teacher, and in a building other than the school, it will do no more serious harm than to add to the Indian's indolence.

Sir,

In further reference to the Beren's River School, I most respectfully beg to state that I am convinced that the attendance there has developed into a contest between the adherents of the Methodist and Catholic Churches respectively.

My office, if nothing else, prohibits me from taking sides with either, it being impossible to be fair to one without being just to all and it appears impossible for justice to be done so long as any Church has any power or influence, whatever in the day schools in the reserves. In the industrial schools it is a different matter, the Indians have a choice and can send their children to an industrial school managed by people of their own faith. I know the Department only grant to the Churches the privilege of appointing the teacher, but this courtesy is often sadly presumed upon and overreached, for in spite of our so called civilization and christianity we are apt to get narrowminded, and perhaps it is only natural, and therefore to be expected, that we should endeavour to enlarge the borders of our tents. From a christian standpoint this is commendable but for the Department, whose attitude must be the same to all Indians, its difficulties and tribulations are, un-necessarily multiplied.

I believe every kindness and assistance possible should be given our Churches to establish Christian teaching to our Indians in the reserves, but, as the bi-lingual system in our white schools has been the cause of race prejudice, in many districts, the abuse of a privilege, in connection with Indian Affairs. The Methodist Missionary at Berens River has reported, in a private communication to me, that splendid progress is being made this academic year, under the faithful and painstaking efforts of Mr. Street. Dear Sir:

I am addressing this letter to you with the hope that it will catch you at the Union Conference. I have no doubt you will meet Mr. Merritt at that point.

You are both cognizant of the fact that Mr. Street has rendered us nearly 3 years of excellent service as teacher at Fort Resolution. Ottawa, April 26, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th ultimo, with enclosures, with reference to friction between the managers of the Protestant and the Roman Catholic Indian Day Schools at Berens River. In reply I have to state the Department believes it is in the best interests of its wards if each child attends a school conducted under the auspices of the church with which the child and its parents are affiliated. This is in harmony with the provisions of the Act which reads (Subsection 1 of Section 10): "No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices."

However, parents may change their religion, and further, the father has the legal right to determine the religious education of his child. Whenever the parents change their religion or a father exercises his right to direct his child's religious education and the child's attendance at one school or another is affected, the Department, if called upon to make a decision, asks for evidence concerning the bona fide nature of the change or of the father's wish.

In practice, if there is doubt concerning the school a child should attend, the Department endeavours to ascertain the religion of the parents and the real wishes of the child. Thus keeping in mind the best interests of the child, a decision is given. The child must then attend the school selected. In the case of residential schools, such attendance must be for the entire tuition period, as it is not considered wise to transfer a child from one residential school which the Department maintains to another for religious reasons.

A child that has been resident in a school may have imbibed religious opinions and even convictions, and it is the Department's opinion that this should be a deterrent. In the case of day schools, the parents are maintaining the child at home, and the Department does not assume as much responsibility in these matters. If the parents have changed their religion or if the father has changed his wishes concerning the religious education of his child, generally speaking the Department does not interfere.

Would you judge me presumptuous now to cite briefly the cause of all the past discord. Many years ago this band of Indian people were won over to Christianity by Protestant Missionaries. Not so many years ago the Roman Catholics began a Mission here. They were able to re-baptize a certain part of the same people into their faith. Now in recent years these same people are coming back to their first faith. Upon doing so they have sent their children to our school. OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I have received a letter from Mr. C. D. Street, the teacher at Berens River, Manitoba, in which he brings before me a question upon which I think I ought to have your advice. The following quotation from his letter dated March 28th, 1935, will place before you the problem:

"Would it seem presumptuous to you if I were to ask you to intervene in a small matter concerning our school? We desire to introduce typing to our advanced pupils. Our chief obstacle is the procuring of one or even two machines. These may be of any kind, even obsolete, as long as the key-board is fairly similar to the later makes. What we want is something to hammer away on until we get the idea of fingering, etc. If we can get such machines then I shall endeavor to take a course in the theory. I am not decided as to the shorthand. Would you advise it?"

You will gather from this that Mr. Street is trying to keep up to date and is endeavoring to interest the young people in the various lines of work. The question in my mind is whether the Department would agree with his proposition to teach the use of the typewriter. We think that we could find him a couple of second hand machines if the Department would be willing that he should put this on his curriculum. I shall be much obliged for your mind on this subject.

I trust that you are all keeping well and that Dr. Stone is improving in health.

With very kind wishes to all,

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

I without presumption draw your attention to the fact that the hours for day schools are perhaps too long. I think your regulations call for 9-12, and 1-4. These hours could be shortened by an hour for the winter months and one-half hour for the summer months. I am sure this would be an improvement. This action need in no way interfere or lessen the efficiency of the school-room education, but may rather increase its capacity for such. The days get real short in the winter and in summer it is important that pupils get a maximum of sunshine, when we remember that T.B. is the worst physical enemy of the Indian. With many day-schools which are not the last word in means of ventilation I do not know of any better suggestion than making it possible for our children to have these added hours of pure fresh air. Where a day-school teacher has say 25 pupils in 5 or 6 grades in a not too large room I submit that he can do better work with the shorter hours.

C.D.S.

Mr. Brown resigned from this position early in the year 1942 and his resignation was accepted by the Department in a letter to the Home Mission Board of the United Church dated June 2, 1942.

Indian day school teachers are classified as temporary Civil Servants. They do not contribute to the superannuation fund and do not qualify for superannuation allowances. A deduction, however, of $6 to the retirement fund is made from their salaries. The amount deducted in each case is returned to the contributor when he leaves the Service. It would appear that a cheque for the sum of $64.08 was sent forward to Mr. Brown in a letter dated August 25, 1942. This cheque, owing to the failure of the postal authorities to locate Mr. Brown, was returned to the Department. This cheque will be sent forward immediately to Mr. Brown at his present address.

There is no definite understanding that Indian day school teachers will be re-employed by this Department at the close of the war and, in view
of the large number of teachers who have joined the Armed Forces, it will be exceedingly difficult to secure positions for all of them. It is our intention, however, to do everything humanly possible to secure schools for returned soldiers with full academic and professional standing.

Director.

I do not know whether leave credits were set up for Mr. Street on his being given permanent status.

Ottawa, August 29, 1945.

Mr. E. McPherson, Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.

The Department has just been advised that Miss Jean Reid gave up duties as teacher of the Berens River United Church School at the end of June and does not intend to return for the academic year 1945-46.

The Board of Home Missions has nominated Mr. Peter Kohler. He is 34 years of age and holds a first class B permanent Manitoba certificate. He has had 5 years' teaching experience.

I enclose the necessary forms which he should complete and return as soon as he begins duties. These forms should be returned to us as soon as possible, as payment of salary cannot be made until they are received here.

For Deputy Minister.

Enc.
Ottawa, August 28, 1945.

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY,

Indian Day School, No. 500.

For Deputy Minister.

Miss Annie Niedrie has been secured to take charge of this school for the month of June 1946 only. Salary should be paid to her at the rate of $50.00 a teaching month and cheque should be drawn in her favour and sent to Mr. K. Robertson, Indian Agent, Selkirk, Manitoba.

I enclose copy of letter of appointment.

For Deputy Minister,

Sir:—

Selkirk, Man., Sept. 10th, 1935.

Dear Sir:

Herewith enclosed please find a letter from the Rev. Mr. Nidari of Berens River which explains itself.

The rain proof roof referred to would have to be shingles. I can only endorse Mr. Nidari's contention that such a building is very badly needed and the cost should not exceed $60.00.

If approved an early reply would be appreciated in order that sufficient time may be allowed to have the job completed before freeze up.

Your obedient servant,

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Selkirk, Man., Sept. 10th, 1935.

Dear Sir:

Mr. C. D. Street of the U.C. Indian Day School at Berens River has written to say that their school stove is in a very bad condition. It is one of those long "Camp Comfort Heaters" and the heat has caused it to buckle in on both sides. This buckling has made a dangerous opening on the front.

Mr. Street states in his letter that the stove is no longer safe and recommends a cast iron box stove, 3 feet six long as being the most suitable for his school. The cost of this stove would be $20.75

If approved kindly advise at earliest convenience in order that shipment may be made before navigation closes.

Your obedient servant,

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, September 13, 1935.

Sir:

With reference to your letters of the 10th instant, I beg to say that you may arrange for the erection of a suitable storehouse at the Barons River U. C. Day School. It is noted that this can be erected at a cost not exceeding $60, including both material and labour.

You may also supply to this school a new box stove, which, it is noted, you can obtain for $20.75.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

June 17th, 1936.

Hon. T. A. Crear,
Minister of the Interior, Ottawa.

Hon. Sir:

We, the undersigned, are extremely loathe to address this letter and request to you; when we are quite aware that it may appear to be a breach of your department's rules; And also when we appreciate the fact that you may be unduly bothered by such requests as we are about to present.

Twenty years ago The Indian Department erected a schoolhouse here twenty feet by thirty feet, with logs for foundation and no concrete. The walls were siding outside, and un-seasoned rough lumber inside building paper (long since rotted or eaten by mice) was put between. It is possible now to shove a pencil through from outside, or from inside.

For some years requests have been made for the erection of a new building, the last one being made last winter. All of these have been turned down, the last one ignored.

Both the Indian Agent and Doctor have seen the building this week. The Doctor thought if a new building were erected, this old one could be used as a dining hall; and playroom in wet weather. The Agent is afraid that it is too late this year for the erection of a new building and thinks the old one could be repaired, and has asked us to send in a requisition for material.

Now, sir, at the risk of being considered presumptuous, we would most earnestly impress upon you the fact that it would be a deterrent to our work here to go into the erection of a new building. For nearly twenty years our children have eaten their mid-day meals on the same desks as they study on. Children roast and freeze at the same time. The place is an ice house not a school house. The foundation is rotten and the walls are weak and only having been held together for some years by an iron rod across in the inside. The roof is buckling and will very soon compel attention, and it would be a very unwise proceeding to spend an amount of money to repair such a building.

Please do not conclude that we are seeking to overrule the agent. We know he has much to contend with and we would not in any way criticize his ruling. However, in the interests of our work here, we feel very much exercised over the fact that now we must have a new building in order to carry on in an efficient manner. We have strong opposition here with two priests and two nuns coming out next month. They have other sources to...
draw from for their buildings, &c., which are denied us. Ours in the reserve school, being situated on the reserve and recognized as The Reserve School, your instant decision and action are much hoped for, and may we hope that two thousand dollars be allowed at once, and the building erected immediately to be ready for September. Rev. J. W. Niddrie, 46 years Missionary to Indians and Mr. C. D. Street, twenty years a teacher.

(Sgd.) REV. J. W. NIDDRIE.

September 5th, 1956

W. J. Sutherland Esq.,
Supt. Indian Education Ottawa,

Dear Sir—

Will you please pardon the liberty I take in trespassing upon your valuable time with this letter, and allow my object to be my apology. First by way of introducing myself to you; may I say that I have just finished 46 years in the active work amongst the Indian peoples. Twenty-one of that time... or nearly so... was spent at Morley Alberta, and the remaining twenty-six... or nearly so... in this north land. Sixteen of this time in the North has been spent at Berens River.

I must submit to you in a most courteous way, for your information a few facts and figures regarding school children and their education at Berens River and other adjacent points. At the present time there is in the course of erection at the Church of Rome Mission here a building which we are told is to be a Residential School. We are further informed that the Dept. of Indian Affairs have contributed the sum of four thousand dollars towards the expense of this building. Now I shall not ask anything at all regarding the number of names appearing on their school register here, as I might be misled, and it is quite unnecessary for me to seek this information from your office as I know every last child of school age belonging to the Church of Rome here.

The children of school age belonging to their Mission... that is Treaty Children number in all six... or at the outside certainly not more than seven. Please note, these are treaty children of school age who owe their allegiance to the Church of Rome here; and we understand that no provision is made in a Mission Indian School by the Dept. of Indians Affairs for "Non Treaty Indian children". We have at our Mission and belonging before United Church Day School here FORTY-FOUR children of school age. Allow me to be still more explicit... four of our children living at five mile point, have been co-opted into the other school but are still Protestant. It seems perfectly impossible to induce the Dept. of Indian Affairs, to assist us, in transporting, and returning these pupils to and from school. I cannot understand it, as the cost would be but small; and in the old days in the west, provision was always made for this. Then the amount of food supplies allowed us for the mid-day meal is altogether inadequate. Please understand I am most respectfully submitting this information for your consideration, and not in a spirit of criticism. At the same time if it is convenient I shall be deeply grateful if you will be kind enough to favor me with a reply as to these matters. We have sent in a Supplemental requisition for more supplies for we always fall short before spring, and our people are living from hand to mouth, and we cannot hope for them to supply lunches for these children. In any case the pupils... should always... during the winter months not only have a mid-day meal; but also a hot cup of cocoa are they begin work in the morning. Coming a considerable distance and being but poorly clothed it seems unreasonable to do their best work.

May I very respectfully point out that very few people upon that Reserve own their allegiance to the Church of Rome; certainly not more than one or two families at the most.

Secondly: At Berens River: We have some two hundred and sixty or more Indians belonging to the Protestant Faiths against some Seventy Roman Catholics.

Again at Little Grand Rapids: The Protestants far outnumber the members of the Church of Rome.

Again at Pakangoom: Not one family to draw pupils from there.

Dear Lake... Again... Not one

We must admit that there are a number of non-treaty children but as we understand it, the Dept of Indian Affairs do not supply schools and teachers for them. We have for considerably over forty years assured the Indians that the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa have and are always ready to assist the Indians in anything that is right and reasonable. Dear Sir,

Relative to our telephone conversation today regarding the erection of a new Indian Day School (W.O.) at Berens River.

While making the annuity payments at Berens River we inspected the present school and interviewed Mr. C.D. Street, schoolteacher, who stated that they would require a school 50 x 30 with a full size basement. The building to have a belfrey and a bell size 22. The School to accommodate 60 pupils. The building to be built on the present site and equipped with storm windows, screens, eavestrough and a furnace. Also to be painted grey.

The old building could be torn down and the lumber used by Indians only for the repair of their homes on the Reserve. The R.C.M.P. could distribute this old lumber.

I would recommend a building of frame construction with a full size basement. I would also recommend that this work be let by contract and that the contractor be allowed to take one man with him and the rest of the labour be taken from the reserve, as there are no Indians competent to do the carpenter work but many could provide the rough labour.

I consider that the school should be equipped with a cloakroom and also two new toilets. The reason we have asked for eavestroughing is to protect the cement basement. The new chimney should be of brick and a full length to the basement.

Building materials could be supplied from Selkirk and should the Department consider building this school this year, I would suggest that the work be started at once in order to be ready by the last of September when school opens.

Yours very truly,

E. McPherson (signed)

Ottawa,
October 14, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant with reference to certain Indian children who are residing with Mr. and Mrs. J.J. Semple near the Berens River U.C. School.

As you mention in your letter the quantity of food supplies requested is not expensive but there are other features of this matter which I believe should receive your further consideration.

It is felt that it is not advisable to encourage miniature residential schools. This Branch has no supervision over Mr. and Mrs. Semple and it would be impossible to ascertain definitely the number of children actually kept by this couple and the arrangements made for the children's maintenance.

As you are aware we have already forwarded supplies for midday meal purposes. It is felt that the arrangement now in effect at Berens River should not have been started without first consulting us.

Children who are residing too far from a day school should be placed in a residential school. If there is no accommodation in any of the residential schools at the moment consideration could be given to discharging from the residential school some children whose parents are able to provide for them and who reside close to a day school and in this way accommodation could be made available for more deserving cases.

Yours truly,

A.G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

1. With reference to the above, I have to report
sometime ago, Mr. McPherson, Esq., schoolteacher for the United
Church Indian Mission called at this office and requested
that I attend an Indian Council meeting in connection with
the demolishing of the old school.

2. This P.M. accompanied by Chief Mr. Berens I
proceeded to the Department school and attended the meeting.

3. After some discussion thirty-eight local Indians
were nominated to demolish the school, beginning May 16th and
in return for their labor each would receive portions of the
used material to repair their homes.

4. Everyone appeared satisfied and the meeting
closed at 4:30 P.M.

5. In conclusion I might say I believe this the
quickest way to demolish the school, and it will help those
who work, as it now stands it spoils the appearance of the
new school and interferes with the playgrounds.

6. I would respectfully request that a copy of this
report be forwarded to Mr. McPherson, Esq., Indian Agent, Selkirk

Berens River, Manitoba.
December 22nd., 1939.

E. McPherson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.

Dear Sir:-

I beg to draw your attention to the fact that seven children of our faith between the ages of six and fifteen are residing on the Berens River Reserve, a distance of from four to five miles away from school. I have been paying a man to bring these children to school by horse and sleigh but find that I am unable to continue, for financial reasons. I understand that the Indian Department is operating school vans on other Reserves, as for instance Fisher River. The man that has been doing this work satisfactory so far is a former Fisher River Indian, now residing in Berens River. He is willing to continue for a consideration of seventy-five cents to one dollar per day.

Please give this your immediate attention that these children may continue to attend school.

Yours very truly,

Signed

"Luther L. Schuetze"
Dear Sir:

Re: School Van for Berens River

I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter received from Luther Schuetze, Missionary at Berens River.

On receiving this letter, I immediately wrote Lance Corporal Galcraft, R.C.M.P., Berens River. I wish to quote the following from Mr. Galcraft's letter:

"The longest distance anyone is from the school is 2½ miles. It seems funny that these children went to school in the past without all this fuss, at least I never heard of any. Mr. Schuetze is only asking for trouble and making the Indians lazy. The man who has been driving these children to school is Alex Cochrane, who is not a member of the Berens River Band and has no right to be living on the Reserve. There are other children going to the R.C. School who do not complain about the distance they have to walk. I understand that Mr. Schuetze wants a school van like they have at Fisher River."

I wish to state that in my opinion Lance Corporal Galcraft has given a very fair view in this matter. I would like to point out that if the Department starts this at Berens River, they will want the same for every Reserve along the Lake. I have had requests of this nature from time to time but the children have always managed to get to school and have done so on this Reserve for many years. You will note in Mr. Schuetze's letter that Cochrane wishes to receive 75¢ to $1.00 per day. I would like the Department to advise me what I should do in a case of this kind.

I cannot understand why Mr. Schuetze is taking up this matter as he is not the teacher on this Reserve. This is not the first time that Mr. Schuetze has interfered in the handling of this Reserve. Lance Corporal Galcraft has always been able to adjust any trouble that has come up on this Reserve.

Very truly yours,

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 25th instant with reference to the request that you have received for the transportation to the day school on the Reserve of certain children who attend the Berens River U.C. Day School.

The Department has no funds for such expenditure at the present time and consequently it is impossible to give any consideration to the matter.

Mr. E. McPherson,
Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.
Re: Inspection of Indian Day Schools—Reserve River, Man.

In connection with the above I beg to report this day, I proceeded to the Roman Catholic Indian Day School for the purpose of making a general inspection.

This school was found in a clean tidy condition except for the latrines which need rebuilding. The school teacher, a Sister of the Roman Catholic Order, was interviewed and had no complaints to make. Thirty-two children are recorded on the register, but only twenty-five were in attendance. Of the thirty-two recorded, fourteen were white or non-native children and the remainder treaty. Various students' books were examined and note was taken of the children's desks. Quite a number of these are broken and need replacing. Approximately thirty single desks would be sufficient.

This P.M., I proceeded to the United Church Indian Day School and found the school in a very neat condition. The teacher Mrs. A. Chenoweth was interviewed and complained of irregular attendance. (This matter is being looked into in course.) Considerable improvement was noticed in the children since a new teacher has been placed there. For instance due to reasons I noticed all the children spoke English instead of Indian, and when examining them during their lessons I found their books exceptionally neat. Forty-two children are recorded here but only twenty-two were present; those recorded are mostly children. During my inspection I noticed the teacher's desk is an old table. If a new desk were supplied it would place this school in first class order.

Further to the above I might add a hot meal is supplied to the children at noon which is very beneficial to them as the larger portion appear undernourished.

I respectfully request that a copy of this report be forwarded to Mr. Macdonald, M.A., Indian Agent, for his information.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of requisition of the 8th instant from the teacher of the Serens River United Church School. He requests 3 screens for windows and one screen door. If you consider these are required, you may arrange for the purchase.

He also requests 15 gallons of paint & paint brushes, one kalsomine brush and 15 gallons of shingle stain. As the total cost of these items will probably exceed $50, purchase will have to be made through our Purchasing Branch. Repeated instructions have been issued to Indian agents to the effect that when purchases exceed $50 detailed information must be given, and such requests should be accompanied by an explanatory letter stating the agent's opinion regarding the request. For instance, in this case very little information has been given regarding the quality of material required, and besides no mention is made of labour. Is it the intention of the teacher to do the work free of charge if the material is supplied? If labour is required, you should state whether Indian or white labour can be secured and the approximate cost. You must realize that our funds are limited and very explicit information must be given so as to enable us to make a decision.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Selkirk, Man., July 29, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Regarding Mr. Brown's requisition for paint, shingle paint, screens, etc. for the Berens River U.C. Indian Day School, I wish to advise that at the time this requisition went forward to the Department we were very busy here as we had just returned from paying Treaty on Lake Winnipeg. I regret very much that we did not attach a letter giving particulars as to the condition of the school, etc. However, I wish to state that at Treaty time I inspected this school and found it badly in need of paint both inside and out. I would recommend that paint be supplied for the outside this year and possibly funds will be available next year to paint the inside. The labour of putting on the paint will be done by the school teacher, assisted by the Indians without any cost to the Department. Regarding the quality of paint, I would consider that a good quality of paint should be supplied.

Relative to the screen windows and the screen door, I wish to advise that when the school was built these items were not supplied. I consider that they are required and I am having them made and shipped at a cost of $20.40 as instructed by you.

Very truly yours,

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.

I would refer you to your letter 125-8-5 of April 11/46 re Voucher No.765, in favor of the Hudson's Bay Co.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT TO THE TRUSTEES
ON HIS OFFICIAL VISIT TO
The School District of United Church Indian Mission School, Manitoba—River
Date of Visit June 10, 1943.

Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Sir:
You are requested to communicate to the Trustees the following remarks respecting the result of my official visit to your school on the above date:

This school is one of the finest that I have visited in my short term as a School Inspector. I was also pleased to note that Manual training equipment has been purchased and has been used for a few months. A new water cooler has been received and also the lunch supplies for the next term.

I am enclosing a Report on buildings and equipment that is used in Manitoba. I would like you to note the comments thereon.

Mr. Street has charge of this school with 39 children enrolled, and 29 were present on this visit. Mr. Street has been engaged in the teaching of Indian children for many years. He has the work of his school very well organized, and the work of the classroom is progressing quite well. I have noticed that the Indian children do not read with much expression, and their voices are low and inclined to be somewhat of a monotone.

I was impressed with the work that has been done in Nature Study, and the collections and designs of leaves is very good. The work of the boys in Manual is very good and leads me to think that a school programme for these children should be made as practical as possible. Here also the writing, printing and drawing are good.

Yours very truly,

John B. Menzies
Gimli, Man.

Comments based on visits to the Indian Schools at Barans River.

I was fortunate on this visit to meet the Indian Agent, Mr. Olson, and had a very interesting and informal chat with him. I regret I was unable to get to the school at Bloodvein.

As a result of observations in classrooms it is my opinion that we should not expect Indian Schools to follow the curriculum of any particular Province. I am becoming a firm believer that the Indian child does require a special Programme of Studies with a trend to the practical, and any approach to the theoretical should be made as practical. My reason for this is that the Indian child has skillful hands and this should be utilized to a much greater extent than it is at present.

With regard to the teachers, I do believe that they should have at least a Normal Training, and also a Course on Special Methods that would be based on the Programme that they would be using.

Yours very truly,

Mr. Pedley,

Referring to the petition sent to the Minister by His Grace the Archbishop of St. Boniface from the Roman Catholic Indians of Berens River asking for the establishment of a day school on their reserve I beg to say that on looking over the pay list I find that 15 of the 21 names attached to the petition appear therein and they have 40 children amongst them. Their ages are not given, but taking the usual average this would give from 15 to 20 children of school age. I may add that the pay list does not show the religious persuasion of any of the Indians, but I take it for granted that the Indians who signed the petition are all Roman Catholics. The census return for the Berens River Band for the year ended 31st of March, 1912, shows that there are 285 Indians in the Band, 239 of whom are Methodist and the balance, 46, are given as Roman Catholics. The Methodists have a large day school on the reserve with an enrolment of from 40 to 50 children out of a school population of 56. No doubt some of the children attending the
the Methodist School are Roman Catholics and if the Department decides to establish a second school on the reserve there would be enough children to justify its doing so.

I may mention that this is one of the reserves in which the religious work was exclusively carried on by the Methodists, but the Roman Catholics have been gradually working in until they have the number of adherents above mentioned.

There is an application now before the Department for the establishment of a boarding school on this reserve under the auspices of the Methodist church.

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to report on the project of a Catholic Day School for Berens River Indian Reserve. I have the following reasons to give in recommendation thereof:

1st.—There are about 30 Catholic children of school age on the Reserve, as appeareth from List enclosed, drawn up by Rev. Father Allard last October.

2nd.—These children and their parents are mostly grouped around the Catholic Mission, and at a distance of about 3 miles from the Methodist Mission and school. As a matter of fact they do not attend the school at the Methodist Mission because of the distance.

3rd.—We have a Missionary stationed at Berens River, which should be a guarantee of permanency and success for the school.

For these considerations I trust the Government will see its way to provide a sum for the construction of said Day School and a salary for the Teacher.

I have the honor to be

A word in regard to the request from the Roman Catholics for a day school at Beren's River. I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th ultimo, containing the suggestion that the sanction of the Department be obtained for the supply of a meal to the children attending the Day School under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, at Berens River.

In reply I beg to state that I will submit this to the Department for consideration, but I must tell you in friendly frankness that I cannot recommend such a measure, and would add that my attitude and report to the Department was exactly the same in the attempt to establish the permanent issue of a mid-day meal to the children attending the Berens River School under the auspices of the Methodist Church, some time back.

The supplying of provisions to Indians, who of all people are surrounded with a liberal supply of natural foods at all times and who of all people know best how to obtain these foods and with small effort augment this supply with plenty of vegetables would seem to educate them to become the very opposite to good citizens, unworthy and certainly unnecessary dependents.

The present time and the prospects for many years to come would seem to emphasize the urgent necessity of teaching the Indians that they must rely upon their own efforts to provide themselves with food, and if we take heed to the warnings of the Authorities and the signs of the times, the unnecessary supply of provisions will only assist to seriously embarrass the Indians and the Government in the future, and may, at least indirectly cause distress.
I quite appreciate your kindly thought towards the Indians and that you are zealous for the education of them, but if their education has to be bought with the gift of foods or anything else, it would be better for all concerned that the schools be closed and all-round waste be saved.

The articles you mention in your second letter should have been delivered to you before this; the 12 boxes of biscuits and a new register I will recommend be sent direct from the Department warehouse.

Dear Sir:

The following is an extract from a letter of the Rev. Arthur Barner who is now visiting the Lake Winnipeg District. He writes from Berens River under date of July 8th—

"The Roman Catholic Church has 156 acres of land here about half a mile west of the Hudson's Bay Buildings, with a church and a small mission thereon. There are stationed here now one Priest, and two Brothers, one of whom, a Mr. Leech is here with the distinct understanding that he shall organize a school. The Priest is now away in Selkirk purchasing lumber, etc., and hiring men to build a school house, which they tell the people will be a Boarding School in which the children will be boarded all week and sent home over Sundays. There seems to be no question that this movement is in progress. The present Chief Berens has not been consulted. He is simply hostile and threatens to go to Ottawa regarding the matter. Mr. Ferrier has been informed."

I am, of course, aware of the regulation of the Department, which provides for the establishment of an additional school where a Roman Catholic or Protestant Minority can furnish Official evidence.
of a sufficient number of children of their denomination.

I had not heard, however, that this Department had provided in their estimates for the building of a Roman Catholic School at Berens River during the present year. I feel quite sure that in any case no Boarding School has been authorized, or in any way provided for by the Indian Dept.

Mr. Barnet, however, is very careful in his observations, and exact in his reports, and I cannot help feeling disturbed as to the effect upon our work at Berens River if the facts are as stated in his letter, even though the course of action reported may not yet have received official sanction by the Indian Dept.

I should be very glad to learn the present position of affairs in the Indian Dept. as relating to the question of schools at Berens River. I also feel that the information contained in Mr. Barnet's letter, unless already known at Ottawa, ought to be put into your hands. Mr. Perrier is on a visit to Nelson House.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

JHA/M.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant embodying an extract from a letter from the Rev. Arthur Burner in reference to the establishment of a Roman Catholic school at Barrens River.

In reply I beg to say that six years ago an application was made for the establishment of a Roman Catholic day school on the Barrens River Reserve. This was renewed from time to time until February of this year, when the Department consented to the establishment of a Roman Catholic day school there, as it was shown that there were a sufficient number of Roman Catholic children of school age to entitle them to a school of their own. Mr. Agent Carter, in a statement of the Roman Catholic children on the Barrens River Reserve, showed that there were twenty-three of school age. The Department agreed to allow a salary of $600.00 a year for a teacher and to pay the ordinary running expenses of the school, such as fuel, books, etc., on condition that a suitable building was provided by the church. The school is in charge of Mr. Frederick Issach.

The Department has no intention of establishing a Roman Catholic boarding school at this point, and in fact a school of this class was never applied for.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I feel it my duty to write you regarding the day schools here at Berens River. At Treaty Time I asked the Inspector Mr. Bunn about the school that the Catholics were building here, as I had heard nothing about it before. He assured me that the Government knew nothing about it and was not giving it their support. However, I am not satisfied as the teacher tells me that the Government is supporting them. I would like to say here that I as chief am not in favor of this school. For years we have been asking for a Boarding School to be erected here under the Methodist Church and were assured that when the Government saw its way clear they would give us one.

One school is enough on this reserve, and I am sorry that just as everything is running smoothly another should come in to make trouble. Our Teacher has been doing good work during the past winter and we would like to see the Government enforce education here and make the children attend the Government school. We thought the Government needed all the money they could get while the war lasted and therefore do not see the necessity of paying two teachers when one can do the work.

Hoping you will give this matter your earliest attention, and waiting your reply. I am Your Obedient Servant.

Ottawa, August 17, 1918.

Dear Chief,

I have your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the opening of a second school on the Berens River reserve. Under Section 97 of the Indian Act, the Roman Catholic minority of the Berens River reserve were entitled to ask for the establishment of the school; this they did, and when it was shown to the satisfaction of the Department that there were sufficient children of school age belonging to that faith on the reserve to warrant the opening of a school, the consent of the Department was given.

Your contention that one teacher could do the work is not borne out by the representations made to the Department, the last census showed that there were over 80 children of school age on the reserve; these could not possibly be accommodated in one building and taught with any proper results by one person.

Chief W. H. Berens,
Berens River,
Man.

With reference to the custody and religious training of Sophia Green, infant daughter of Guthbert Green, who was adopted by Mr and Mrs. Tache Green, as referred to in a copy of F. Leach's letter to Agent Colcleugh dated the 8th September, 1919, hereunder, I beg to say that where a father abandons, forfeits or waives his right to the custody of his child allowing it to be reared in a faith not his own, as Mr. Green has done by agreement of adoption dated the 15th day of September, 1913, in an action being taken by either of the parties for the custody of such child, the courts would consider only the happiness and benefit of the child. The Department takes no responsibility as to enforcing agreements for adoption of Indian children. There is no provision in the Indian Act authorizing the Superintendent General to take and place an adopted child in the custody of its adopted parents. If the McKays insist on the return to them of Sophia Green, their only course is to take proceedings in the Court. If such action were taken, I am of the opinion that the Court would direct this child's father to compensate the McKays for the maintenance of the child during the time that they kept
it, if the Court allowed the father to take it away from them.

I presume that this child's annuity has been paid to the McLays since its adoption by them and I think it would be proper to continue such payment until such time as they may be considered to have received reasonable compensation.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant.

In reply I beg to enclose herewith a copy of Indian day school regulations which will give you full information regarding the teaching days, holidays, etc., in Indian day schools.

Regarding the bonus, I beg to state that, during the present fiscal year ending March 31st, next, bonus has been granted to teachers of Indian day schools at the rate of $15.00 per month for the 10 teaching months or $150.00 for the teaching year. For the December quarter you were paid bonus at the above rate, and a cheque for $45.00 was sent you covering the bonus due for the months of October, November and December, last.

Regarding the education of non-treaty children, I beg to say that, if they are children of Indian parents, this department is responsible for their education. In the case of children of half-breeds who reside on a reserve and live the Indian mode of life thereon, the Department allows them to attend its schools, but we are not responsible for the education of half-breed children who do not reside on a reserve.

Your obedient servant,

CANADA
Ottawa, August 12th, 1925.

Very Rev. Sir,

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, relative to teachers for the next school year for the Barona River R.C. and Bloodvein R.C. Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the transfer of Miss Patricia Fuller, who is now teacher at the Barona River School, to take charge of the Bloodvein School.

We will also approve of the appointment of Rev. Brother Leach as teacher of the Barona River School to succeed Miss Fuller. The salary allowed Rev. Father Leach will be at the rate of $80 per month for 10 teaching months in the year. It is understood that, besides the teaching of the school, he will be responsible for the dispensing of medicines to the Indians at Barona River.

He will allow Miss Fuller salary at the same rate as she was paid at Barona River, viz., $80 per month for the 10 teaching months in the year, and she should also attend to any dispensing of medicines that will be required.

We are informing Mr. Agent Latulippe and Mr. Commissioner Graham of the approval granted for the above appointments for the next school year.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Very Rev. J. B. Baye, O.M.I.,
300 Provencher Ave.,
St. Boniface, Man.

Berens River, Man.
Feb 16th 1927.

The Acting Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I beg to submit the following facts for your consideration.

I am the Day School Teacher in the Roman Catholic Day School at Berens River. My name is signed in full hereunto.

My quarterly salary cheques have been coming to me through Mr. Inspector Bunn of Winnipeg, and at his suggestion I am addressing this letter to you. All cheques to date have been received.

As you are aware I am located at some distance from a bank, and I do not like to have so much money on hand as my salary cheque amounts to. I would be obliged if my salary cheques could be sent to my credit at the Bank of Montreal at Selkirk, Man.
I have asked Mr. Inspector Burrell to arrange this for me and he will get a pass book and blank cheque forms and fix it so that I can draw my own cheques for such amounts as I might want from time to time as I require money.

Your obedient servant,

Boniface Guimond.

Witnesses:
Esther Bittern
Girard Patrick
Winnipeg, 2nd March, 1927.

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir:

Herewith I am enclosing a letter received from Boniface Guimond of the Fort Alexander Band, under No. 175 of that band. This young man is the Teacher of the Day School, R.C., at Berens' River, and I am informed that he is making good.

The enclosed letter intimates what the young man desires to do. I suggested to him that this would be a good thing for him to do, and the letter enclosed is his response.

He sent this to me and I wish to arrange this along the lines he asks when his next quarterly cheque comes to hand.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
