MEMORANDUM

Representative of the Treasury,

Re School No. 501a.

As Rev. F. Leach, O.M.I., has been transferred from the Berens River R.C. Indian Day School from September 1st, 1936, his name should be omitted from the September paylist in connection with this school.

You will be advised at a later date regarding the name of the teacher who will succeed Rev. F. Leach.
Ottawa, August 11, 1936.

Dear Sir:

On the nomination of the Reverend Oblate Fathers, the Department is approving the appointment of a Reverend Sister as teacher of the Berens River R.C. Indian Day School for the academic year 1936-37.

The name of this Sister will be forwarded to you in the near future. She will be allowed salary at the rate of $80.00 per teaching month. Please give her every possible assistance.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

E. McPherson, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.
October 13, 1936.

MEMORANDUM

Representative of the Treasury,

Re: School No. 501.

Sister M. Phillippe de Neri has replaced Rev. F. Leach, O.M.I., as teacher of the Berens River R.C. Indian Day School from September 1st, 1936, with salary at the rate of $80 a teaching month. Her services will be continuous from that date.

As no payment of salary was made to the teacher at this school for the month of September, she should be allowed two months' salary on the October paylist, as follows:

501 - Sister M. Phillippe de Neri - Berens River - $800 - $160.00 Man.
October 13, 1936.

MEMORANDUM

Representative of the Treasury,

Re: School No. 501a.

Sister M. Phillippe de Neri has replaced Rev. F. Leach, O.M.I., as teacher of the Barrens River R.C. Indian Day School from September 1st, 1936, with salary at the rate of $80 a teaching month. Her services will be continuous from that date.

As no payment of salary was made to the teacher at this school for the month of September, she should be allowed two months' salary on the October paylist, as follows:

501 - Sister M. Phillippe de Neri - Barrens River, - $800 - $160.00 Man.
June 12, 1937.

MEMORANDUM:

Representative of the Treasury.

Re: School No. 301.

Two teachers have been employed at the Berens River R.C. School since September 1, 1936, but it was only recently that the Minister formally approved of the second teacher. At that time, his approval was also obtained for an increased salary for the senior teacher.

The following are the salary rates which have been approved for the two teachers at this school:

- Sister M. Philippe de Neri - $1,000 a year
- Sister M. des Oliviers - $900

As Sister M. Philippe de Neri has only been paid at the rate of $800 a year from September 1st, 1936, to May 31st, 1937, there is a balance due her of $100.00. She is now entitled to this balance plus salary for June, making a total of $200.00.

Sister M. des Oliviers is entitled to salary for the period September 1, 1936, to June 30, 1937, amounting to $900.00.

In view of the above, the following entries should appear on the June paylist in connection with the Berens River R.C. School:

- 501 - Sister M. Philippe de Neri - Berens River, Man. - $200.00
- 501 - Sister M. des Oliviers - $900.00

(Copy of memorandum to Dr. McGill dated May 5, 1937, attached hereto.)
Ottawa, March 17th, 1947.

Memorandum

CHIEF TREASURY OFFICER

Re: Berens River R.C. Indian Day School #501.

Please note that Sister Marie-Louise Laercoix, assistant teacher at this school, is obliged to give up duties owing to illness. She should be allowed salary for the month of March, 1947 and no further payment should be made to her after March 31st.

She has been replaced by Sister Pauline Pulvermacher effective March 1st, 1947 at a salary of $90.00 a teaching month.

The Indian Agent

Dear Sir,

After experiencing the winter in the above school and observing the suffering of the children caused through the absolutely inadequate care, which as teacher, I have been unable to give them, I am resolved to plead on their behalf, to the Government's generosity for aid in providing them with better care for the next winter.

The aid I would ask is a log house, size 20x30 ft., half of which I could use as a home for myself, the other half would be a dinning room and rest room for the scholars.

Under the present conditions, the children walk two and three miles, crossing the open lake in the bitterest weather, and remaining all day without even a cup of hot water.

When taken suddenly sick, as repeatedly happened in this February and March epidemic of La Grip, I had only the cold floor on which to lay them.

With the above building opening into the schoolroom, I could provide decent care in cases of emergency, without neglect of the other scholars, and hot meals at noon, which I am positive would prevent much of the sickness among the children in the winter time.

My idea of living in the building myself, is to be in a position to train the girls in housekeeping and cooking, of which they stand in so much need as future wives and mothers.

Also I would open up free classes of child nursing and care, and sick nursing, both for the girls and for the present mothers, which I feel would reduce much of the sickness and death which now prevails in the reserve.

Trusting my plea will appeal to the Government's generosity,

I remain
Yours faithfully
(signed) Patricia F. Fuller
Teacher.

In reply I beg to say it is noted that both these schools closed at the end of May and will re-open on the last of August, next. The salary for the June quarter is being paid to the teacher of each of these schools for two months.

With reference to the request of the teacher for the building of a lavatory at the Berens River R. C. School and your estimate as to the cost, I beg to say that you may arrange during the present holidays to have a suitable building erected. You may also arrange for the purchase and delivery to the school of 24 cups, 6 spoons, 6 plates, 100 pounds beans, 100 pounds rice, 20 pounds cocoa and 1 case milk. I may say that we are placing an order with the Government Stationery Office to forward the stationery, etc., asked for by the teacher for the use of the classroom. We are ordering the anatomy chart asked for by the teacher, but I would point out that this chart, which costs $15, is not authorized for the use of day schools. However, after the report as to the benefits which she derives from its use, we are making an exception in this case. The teacher should see that the chart is properly cared for.

I attach voucher #336/24 for $55.93 for extra lumber used in addition to Berens River R.C.Day School. This building (see Dept letter #125-16-5, dated 21st June) as originally estimated on, was intended to be a log building, separate from the school and to be used as teachers residence and dining and rest room for the pupils. As the Indians did not get out the logs last winter, the R.C. missionary and the school teacher decided to build an all frame "lean to" addition to the school, which they considered would be more convenient and require less fuel in the winter, than two separate buildings. When I was at Berens River in July on my inland trip, the building, as a "lean to" had been started and I thought with a little more expense it could be carried to the height of the school house and give more accommodation for the teacher upstairs. This alteration I promised to take up with the Department on my return, but owing to a misunderstanding they went ahead, and on my return from inland the building was completed. Father Grandpré had supplied the extra material required from lumber he had bought for another building and has sent in the bill for amount, as above stated.

Sir:

Referring to your letter No. 125-16-4 of 21st ultimo authorizing the purchase of a small amount of mid-day meal supplies for the Berens River R.C. Day School, I beg to advise you that the School Teacher, Mr. F. Leach, called at the office today enquiring about these supplies. I read the department letter to him and he expressed his regret that these supplies had been reduced to such an extent. He pointed out that there was no necessity to supply sugar, if the tea and rice were cut out.

He also informed me that the teacher at the protestant school at Berens River had told him that he had received all the mid-day meals requisitioned for this year and that the fact that one school would be in a position to give the pupils a hot lunch, would tend to greatly reduce the attendance at the school where none was provided.

He requested me to write to the department and asked them to reconsider their decision.

Kindly answer by return mail so that these supplies can go forward as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I beg to refer you to a letter dated October 8th, addressed to the then Deputy Superintendent General, Department of Indian Affairs, and signed by the Acting Deputy Minister of Public Works, enclosing an account for dredging at Berens River in September.

The cost of the work as shown by this account is in excess of the amount that was considered the work would cost when same was authorized. As explained in your letter this high cost was due, no doubt, to difficulties over which you had no control.

As this department has only a limited appropriation available for this work, I would be very glad if you could give consideration to reducing the amount charged to cover only the time taken up by the dredge until it left Berens River.

I am anxious to have this account which is outstanding settled, and will be pleased to have your reply as soon as possible, as it will be necessary to submit a memorandum to Council.

January 4, 1937

Dear Sir:

I have given consideration to your letter of December 25, 1936, in reference to the account rendered by your Department for dredging at Berens River, in September last.

Irrespective of the work of the dredge, the total account rendered this Department for tug hire for towing amounts to $8,600., which expenditure would certainly not have been necessary had the Department not acceded to the request from your Minister to stop at Berens River and do certain dredging there. It was, therefore, considered only fair that the account covering the lay time at Berens River, the towing from Hanusa to Victoria Beach and the lay time at Victoria Beach should be met by your Department.

Our District Engineer reports that unless this amount is collected from the Department of Indian Affairs he will not have sufficient money to maintain the half-pay men employed on this Department's plant during the winter, as this additional tug hire has eaten into the amount allotted for that purpose. However, as you say your Department has also only a limited appropriation for this work, I am willing to meet you by offering to split the total towing account of $8,600., in two, your Department bearing one-half, $4,300., and this Department a similar amount, which would, in effect, reduce the account rendered from $1,797.50 to $1,300., a reduction of $497.50.

I trust this will enable you to get this outstanding account settled.

Yours sincerely,

J.F. Hunter
Deputy Minister

Dear Sir,

Les Pères Oblats de M. I. have recently completed a building at Berens River, Manitoba, for the staff employed in Indian welfare work in that section of the country. This building includes necessary living accommodation for the staff of four (4) Sisters and, also, sufficient room to operate a small hospital. At the present time, there is a staff of four (4) Reverend Sisters, one of whom is in charge of the Berens River R. C. Day School and the other three are handling the hospital work and the social work among the adult Indians of the reserve.

I am attaching to this letter a signed blueprint showing the size and dimensions of the building. I also attach a photograph of the building.

The expenditure by Les Pères Oblats to October 1st, 1936, amounted to $9,821.51. Since that time, we have found it necessary to incur an additional expenditure of $1,300.00, which makes the total cost approximately $11,000.00. I understand that an Order-in-Council has been passed authorizing the grant to the Reverend Pères Oblats of $4,000.00 towards the cost of this building. I would appreciate if cheque for this amount could be forwarded at once to Les Pères Oblats de M. I., 340 Provencher Ave., St. Boniface, Man.

On behalf of Les Pères Oblats, I desire to express our appreciation of the grant that has been made and I trust that the Department will find it possible to favourably consider reimbursing us for our total expenditure and, by so doing, assume complete ownership of this building, which we feel was much needed on the Berens River Reserve. As I mentioned above, this building provides both hospital accommodation and living quarters for a staff who will, in our opinion, give very devoted services to the Indians.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

For Les Pères Oblats de M. I.
Referring to your memorandum of the 3rd instant, relative to providing a grant to the amount of $4,000 towards the cost of the construction of a combined teachers' residence and small hospital erected by the authorities of the Oblate Order at Berens River, Manitoba, I would say that this is a frame building, two stories high, on a cement foundation. The building provides living accommodation for a staff of four (4) Sisters; one of whom is the teacher in the Berens River R.C. Day School and the other three have charge of the hospital work and the social work among the adult Indians of the reserve. This building will be used by the Church authorities as a residence and small hospital, also to provide living accommodation and school facilities for six (6) to eight (8) Indian children who will be kept in residence.

The expenditure by the Oblate Order on the construction of the building to October 1st, 1936, amounted to $9,821.51, and they state that, since that time, they have incurred an additional expenditure of $1,300., making the total cost of the building approximately $11,000. A blueprint of plan of building has been submitted by the Oblate Order.

The necessary Order-in-Council having been secured, I recommend that you approve the payment of $4,000 to Les Reverend Peres Oblats, which is the amount provided towards the cost of the construction of the building.

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of

I have the honour to inform you that day school at the Big Eddy has been closed for past month, the teacher Mr. Bagshaw being unable to attend on account of illness, and the Doctor does think he will be able to resume his duties for least two or three weeks to come.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant

The Secretary.

Department of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa.
Ottawa, March 13th, 1910.

Sir,

The report of Mr. Agent Fischer on the Big Eddy school shows that the average attendance at this school for the month of February was only 6, although there are 23 children enrolled. This is a very poor showing and leads the Department to take into consideration means of improvement.

You will be good enough to visit the parents and impress upon them the necessity for sending their children regularly to school. The experience of the Department shows that the matter of attendance is one which rests very largely with the teacher. If he is interested in his work and enthusiastic and also makes the school attractive to the children there is generally little cause for complaint in so far as attendance is concerned.

The Department would, therefore, like you to use every effort to effect an improvement and it is to be hoped that the next report from the Agent will show a decided change for the better.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

R. H. Bagshaw, Esq.,
Teacher,
Big Eddy Indian School,
The Pas, Sask.
A well attended school is an encouragement to any teacher, and will stimulate him to making efforts in the work; but a poorly attended school, which is caused by the indifference of parents, will discourage the bravest of teachers.

Dear Sir, as a servant of the Department who always tries and has tried for more than 15 years faithfully to do his duty, though often discouraged, I beg you to consider the present state of things, particularly here at The Pas, where the white population is on the increase, bringing with it attractions which are not good for the Indian any more than the White man, making parents more careless and indifferent than before towards their families.

Do not hold the Teacher responsible for these irregular attendance of children, but establish one of two things, either a Boarding School, or Compulsory Education in the Way Schools for a definite number of days in each year, then I think good results may be looked for.

I have the honour to remain

Your obedient servant,

P. H. Bagshaw (Indian Teacher)
instead of going to school.

I have here shown to defend myself, and the Teachers in Indian Schools, from the injustice of laying the blame on them, instead of placing it on the right shoulders, which is first the parents, then the Department, and lastly the Teachers.

I always amongst the Indians for their future welfare as well as the present, and believe that all Indian Teachers have striven to do the same, until discouraged by the prevailing circumstances.

If the Department fully realized (as those who are working amongst the Indians do) the rapid change from morality to immorality which takes place as soon as civilization comes into their midst, undoing all the good that has been done in the past by Teachers as well as missionaries, they (the Department) would lose no time in taking measures to enforce all that is good for the welfare of the Indian and community at large.

The Teacher needs the Department to back him up, so his work at best, is discouraging, and when the Department takes the side of the Indian against the Teacher, the Indian is not slow to perceive it, and the result is injurious to one and all.
You want the Teacher to interest, and attract; there are essentials which must be applied in all schools, but the Indian child needs a great deal of variation, and these alone without good discipline, and the cultivating of self reliance, will not make good men and women of them.

I shall endeavour to do my best to improve the attendance this quarter; but owing to the prosperous time in cat hunting, the first 6 weeks of quarter will be influenced for the worse, as most of the children will be away with their parents.

I regret to state that the average which I gave Mr. Fisher for the month of February was not correct, as I gave him by mistake, the average of scholars, which included Non Treaty Indians. The correct average was only 4, and not 6 for February; and now at the end of quarter, the average is only 3.96.

You will notice in the column for remarks on Quarterly Returns, I have given an explanation for the irregularity of each scholar, and you will also notice that only 15 out of 25 children, whose names are on the Register attended School at all.

When I go to school in the morning, I often meet children going to the stores with their parents, or others.
that the child was sent to school, but went off with some other children instead, elsewhere.

As you request me to visit the parents in order to get the children to school, I take it for granted that you would have me do it in school hours, as you surely do not expect the teacher to do so in his own time, when the salary granted by the Department is so small.

Under the present circumstances, I cannot visit in my own time, as the Department does not provide houses for the teachers, and the present shack is not large enough to accommodate a white man, with his wife and family; therefore I return to The Pas every evening after school, which is 4 miles distant.

I cannot understand why the teacher should be blamed for the non-attendance of scholars, without any justifiable complaint being made against him; the blame is the parents, and as they are unable to rule their children for their own benefit, the Department must act for them, by compelling them to attend school.

There are very few Indians who really value the efforts that are made for their children.

Unless discipline and independence are taught and impressed upon the children, the next generation will be worse than the present.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant in reference to your work as teacher of the Big Eddy day school in the Pas Agency.

In reply I beg to say that the letter of March 15th, last, was not written as a criticism of your efforts at this school, but with a view of impressing upon you the necessity for a teacher interesting himself in the parents as a means to inducing regular attendance. The difficulties with which you and other Indian school teachers have to contend are well known to the Department, but, notwithstanding this, many of the teachers of our Indian schools, even in the more remote districts, are meeting with splendid success and the personality of the teacher is perhaps the greatest force for good. Where a feeling of confidence is established between the parents and the teacher the apathy of the former is generally to a large extent overcome and the necessity for reverting to more extreme measures, such as provided in the Regulations relating to the education of Indian children, avoided.

It is hoped that future returns will show some improvement in the attendance at your school.

Your obedient servant,
